- - - EXAMINATION
Good afternoon, Ms. Mendez.
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Good afternoon.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: My name is Kim Frascella.  I represent Mr. Hunter in this litigation. Have you ever given a deposition before?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm going to start by giving you some instructions.
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: My first instruction is going to be that all your responses need to be verbal. If you nod your head or say uh-uh or uh-huh, that cannot properly be reflected on the stenographic record.
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If you give that type of response, either I will or your attorney will prompt you to give a verbal response, okay?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If you don't understand one of my questions, please let me know, and I'll rephrase it for you, okay?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If you don't know an answer to one of my questions or don't recall specific information, it's perfectly acceptable to tell me that.
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No one here wants you to guess.  If you can estimate things like time or distance, that would be appreciated.  But if you just don't know or can't say, you can state that for the record, okay?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I ask that you wait until I complete my question before you begin your answer so that we're not speaking over one another. It's difficult for the court reporter to take down what's being said if we're talking over one another, okay?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You seem emotional already, and we haven't even gotten started.  Can I ask you why?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: It's difficult seeing the gentleman.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why is it difficult?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Are you okay?  Do you want to step out for a moment with me?  Are you all right?
speaker: MR. DALY

text: It's difficult seeing the gentleman because since the day of the accident everything pretty much went bad, was ruined.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there anything in particular that occurred at the scene of the accident that's making you upset here today?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I was with my daughter.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: She has another lawyer. Are you aware of that?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you her Power of Attorney?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you her legal guardian?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you sign the letters of representation for the other lawyer for her for Mr. Wilson?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: This accident occurred on June 10, 2018, correct?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What time of day did it occur?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you tell me if it was during the day, afternoon, evening?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: In the afternoon.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What were the weather conditions?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: It was rainy, grayish, muggy weather.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: My understanding is you were operating the vehicle that was involved in the accident on June 10, 2018, correct?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What vehicle were you operating?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: It was a Ford, white Ford.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it a Bronco?  Was it an SUV?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I think it was an Explorer.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You owned that vehicle on that day?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long had you owned that vehicle?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you still own that vehicle?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: On the day of the accident, were you married?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: On the day of the accident, did you live with anyone other than your children?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Can you repeat that question?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Other than your children, as of the day of the accident, did anyone else live with you?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: My mother.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's your mother's name?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Julia Rios.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's your full name, ma'am?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Jessica Mendez.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever been known by any other names?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever been married?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I saw in your answers to interrogatories you provided the names of two gentleman, Ray and Antonio?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who are those gentleman?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Those gentleman were there the day of the accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say they were there, where?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: On Broad Street when we had the accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You're saying they were witnesses to the accident?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you spoken to either of them since the day of the accident?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you call anyone from the scene of the accident?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Repeat that question.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you call anyone from the scene of the accident?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who did you call?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Everyone; my mom, my sister, my kids' father.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did he come to the scene?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did any of your relatives or friends that you contacted from the scene of the accident arrive on the scene?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I called the police.  They came first. Then my dad came.  Then my sister came.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's your dad's name?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Well, step-dad, but I call him dad. Sorry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's fine.
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: His name is Juan.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Juan what?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Alverado.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What about your sister, what's her name?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Veronica.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's her last name?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Alverado.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: My understanding is your daughter's last name is Alverado, as well?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Does she have any relation to Juan, your daughter?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Step-granddaughter.  I call him dad.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm not trying to be smart when I ask that question.  They just have a similar name.  I want to know whether or not they are biologically related in any way.
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did your step-father and your sister arrive separately?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I don't recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did your stepfather or sister arrive before or after the police?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: After.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there anyone else who could have been operating your vehicle at the time of the accident?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you give me a physical description of your daughter, please.
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: She's small.  She looks like a nine-year-old little girl.  She weighs about 90 pounds.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How old is she?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: She's 19 now.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: My understanding is she does have some sort of disability, correct?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is the nature of that disability?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Microcephaly, pachygyria, cerebral palsy.  She also has seizures.  She gets seizures.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Does she speak?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How does she communicate?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Hand signals, not sign language, kind of mumbling.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: She's never been given -- you ever see the tablets that some children with disabilities have to communicate with those?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: It's too complicated for her.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is she able to walk?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: She doesn't have a wheelchair?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: She does have a wheelchair.  Because she has cerebral palsy, it's difficult for her to walk.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At the scene of the accident, was she able to exit the vehicle and stand?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: We had to pick her up.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You say we?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Me and one of the gentleman that were there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did you first speak to either Ray or Antonio at the scene?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: All I remember we had the accident, and the gentlemen came running to the car. That's the first time I ever seen them and spoke to them.  I don't know who they were.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Both of them at the same time?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: One came first and one was trying to turn off the car because the car was smoking. I was panicked, and my daughter was screaming.  She was going through a panic attack.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I read in your interrogatories that at the time of the accident she was asleep; is that correct?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yeah, she was like -- I don't know -- like dozing off, not sleep sleep.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where was she seated in the vehicle?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: In the front.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Passenger seat?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did either of those gentleman, Ray Or Antonio, indicate to you that they witnessed the accident?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were they there when the police arrived?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they speak to the police?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you seen the police report in this case?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know whether or not either one of them were indicated on the police report?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Not that I know of, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know specifically who said what or who saw what?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you give me a general idea of what they communicated to you at the scene?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: They were trying to help me exit the car because it was smoking.  It was pretty bad.  There was things leaking, and they were scared it was going to catch on fire or something.  They were trying to help my daughter out of the vehicle with myself. I cannot specifically say who went after the other gentleman.  I was standing with one of them.  I don't remember.  Maybe if I see them, I'll be like, okay, you're this one, and you're the one that was standing next to me. One of them went after the gentleman, and one of them was with me to help take my daughter out of the car.  That was pretty much it.  They were like, are you okay?  We saw everything.  We're going to go stop the gentleman because he kept on going.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where did he go?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: He just kept on going.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where did he go?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: He just kept on going, moving his car as if he was going to leave.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: My understanding is that Conlyn Street dead ends into Old York Road, right?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I think so.  I don't recall the streets.  I just remember I was going down Broad Street.

text: Are you familiar with that area?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where do you live in relation to the area?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I live here in Philadelphia.  I don't know what you call my mom's area.  It's close to Allegheny, like 5th and Allegheny.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You're not familiar with the area where the accident occurred?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.  That part up there, I think, is called Cheltenham, if I'm not mistaken, or is close to Cheltenham.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After the accident occurred, where did you see my client's vehicle?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I didn't see it until after I was leaving to go to the emergency room. Everything was just really, really crazy, and this car was way off to the -- going this way to the right side.  There is a gas station, and his car was parked on the other side where the gas station was at.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: To the right of you?
speaker: MR. DALY

text: Yeah, this way.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: To the right?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yeah, we're going this way, and he just kept on going.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You were going southbound on Broad Street?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yeah, towards Temple.

text: What do you mean?

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I think there was two.

text: What lane were you in?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: On Broad Street.

text: I don't remember.

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: With their father.

text: Yes.

text: Two.

text: How old are they?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Like right in front of me.

text: Did you get a ticket?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.

text: Where did the vehicles come into contact?

text: I don't understand.

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: The middle of his car, front middle.

text: No.

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: It was drizzling and muggy and darkish.

text: I don't remember.

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yeah, like turning.  I know I'm in my two lanes and Broad Street is a big intersection, so two lanes on one side, two lanes on the other side.  It was like swoosh right in front of me so fast.

speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How was traffic?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: It was light.  It wasn't heavy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you present when my client spoke to the police?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I know the police came.  I did not want to see your client.  My main concern was with my daughter.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You didn't hear any conversation between the police and my client?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.  The police kept, I think, your client apart from me, and me and my daughter were apart on the other side.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there any particular reason for that?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: I was just worried about my daughter. My daughter was screaming and panicking.  One of the gentleman -- I don't recall who, Anthony or the other guy -- they actually helped me out by getting your client's information because I was a nervous wreck.  I was concerned with my daughter.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did either one of those gentlemen speak to my client?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Not that I recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How did they get my client's information?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Well, they went and when the police got there, the police asked the gentleman -- they were there.  They were really helpful keeping me calm and they took the police over there to where your client was at.  They came back.  That's how I got a picture of your client's information and stuff.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you get an incident report with the police report number on it at the scene? Did the police give you that?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: They gave me a little yellow slip with some numbers on it.  I had to wait for that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did the police ask you if you were injured at the scene?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.

text: What did you respond?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they call an ambulance?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: They said just to go to the emergency room.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they ask if you needed an ambulance?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: They did.  It just never got there.  I called 911 and it just never got there and my daughter panicking everything.

text: When you called 911, did you specifically request an ambulance?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Yes, I said can I get assistance because I have my daughter, and it even took long for the police to get there.

text: How long?
speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: It took a while, and it just felt like forever for them to get there.

text: Yes.  You can read it to yourself.

text: Okay.

text: Yes.

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: No.

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA

text: Has your client had any medical episodes or injuries since your accident that prohibits them from doing those things?

text: Yes.  My client has tried taking herself a bath and doing things on her own where she has injured herself.  It's rough because I used to help her and do it for her. She doesn't want anyone else looking at her and taking care of her and that's understandable.  She tries doing it on her own, and she's hurt herself a few times.

text: She's so heavy.  She puts her weight on me, and my back hurts and my left arm has been getting numb.  She tries to put a lot of her weight on my right side.

speaker: MS. FRASCELLA
